attributes.action: Campaign for all NHS workers to be given a tax break during COVID-19 outbreak
attributes.additional_details: The NHS workers are working long, tiring hours to provide care. Often they are over worked and are working over time. After tax, this overtime is often not very much considering the dangerous and risky jobs they are undertaking. I believe it would show appreciation and support to those working with the most vulnerable and risking their own lives to help, such as nurses, health care assistants and paramedics.
attributes.background: For the duration of caring for patients during the coronavirus pandemic, NHS workers should be given a tax break or pay less tax for this period. This would show support to their dedication in caring for the population during this difficult time.

rejection.details:
You may wish to sign this petition calling for the same action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/304595

You can find out more about coronavirus and how you can protect yourself and others here:

NHS website: https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/coronavirus-covid-19/
UK Government website: https://www.gov.uk/coronavirus

You can read NHS tips to help if you are worried about coronavirus here: https://www.nhs.uk/oneyou/every-mind-matters/coronavirus-covid-19-anxiety-tips

You may also be interested to know that because of the large number of petitions that have been started in relation to coronavirus, the Petitions Committee has been questioning the Government about its response to the coranavirus outbreak.

On Wednesday 25 March the Committee questioned Government Ministers and the Deputy Chief Medical Officer Jenny Harries on the Government’s response to the Coronavirus pandemic. You can find out more about this session here: https://committees.parliament.uk/committee/326/petitions-committee/news/145767/committee-question-deputy-chief-medical-officer-and-ministers-on-coronavirus-response/

On Monday 30 March the Chair of the Committee wrote to Government ministers of several departments asking for responses to a number of questions raised by petitions, and suggested by the public in response to a survey distributed to signatories of petitions on coronavirus. You can read these here: https://committees.parliament.uk/committee/326/petitions-committee/publications/3/correspondence/
